titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Saturday.

I had called a final meeting of the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest, at half past 9 this morning, and yesterday sent round by one of the pages a notification to all the members of the Committee in the house— I had also personally notified George S. Houston—but the only members who attended were Brengle, French, and Yost to whom I read the report and bill that I had prepared, both which they approved and authorised me to present after obtaining the consent of one more member of the Committee, to the house— That consent I afterwards obtained from Emery D. Potter, the member from Ohio— At the house there was an hour’s debate on two Resolutions offered by Parmenter 1. That the daily hour of the meeting henceforth should be 10. O’Clock A.M. 2. That the house should daily take a recess from half past 2 to 4. O’Clock P.M. To which Charles J. Ingersoll offered as an amendment that the house should sit till 8 O Clock every evening— There was no opposition to the first Resolution, which was at last unanimously adopted. But White, Speaker of the last house strenuously opposed the 2d resolution for the daily recess, which he urged experience had proved to be worse than useless waste of time. It was struck out by tellers 65 to 61. Ingersoll’s amendment was declared by the Speaker to be not in order. The motion to adjourn being by a rule of the house always in order. Reding moved that debate should cease on the Memphis Navy-Yard Bill, in one hour after it shall be taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— As he pleaded hard for two hours, and then for an hour and a half which was carried— The private Calendar was then taken up, and 76 private bills were passed— That for Seth Sweetser and that for Francis Casaux were laid on the table and that for H De Peyster laid aside. The house, after several abortive motions to adjourn yielded to one shortly before 5. and at 6. I went and dined with Mr Pakenham the British Minister. I have minuted in the margin the names of all the company at this dinner— Waddy Thompson has just returned from his mission to Mexico, and greeted me, with kindness for Massachusetts of outward cordiality! the snake! Robert C. Winthrop told me he had received a Letter from his relative George W. Erving, relating in part to me, and of which he gave me the general purport, to be remembered.
2. V. Sunday

I received yesterday a printed note of invitation— “Rachel Priestman a minister of the Gospel in the Society of Friends, has appointed a meeting for Divine Worship, to be held in the Capitol to-morrow morning at 11. O’Clock to which thou art respectfully invited.” I attended accordingly. She preached from the Clerk’s table where two men and two women of her company were seated with her.— After sitting about 20 minutes in silence she took off and laid aside her black bonnet and rising began rather suddenly, “This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save Sinners.” from this text 1 Timothy 1.15. without so naming it, she discoursed nearly an hour in the peculiar canting tone of Quaker Oratory, slow, distinct and loud articulation without a moment’s loss of words, but within almost every sentence, a pause and hitch to take breath, repeating almost every verse in Paul’s epistles impressing the doctrine of Salvation by Faith in Christ Jesus.— Her exhortations were full of unction and intensity— She finished as abruptly as she had begun, and sat down, apparently exhausted— The house was well filled and attentive Some of the auditory thinking the service over began to move, but a man of her company requested them not to depart, and they resumed their Seats. After an interval of about 5 minutes she kneeled and made a fervent affectionate and passionate prayer in behalf of her hearers, not omitting a supplication to God to turn their hearts to dissolve the ties of bondage, and let the oppressed go free After the service was over, she came with her husband I suppose, to my seat and shook hands with me; as did with Mr Giddings a young woman from Ohio namedI walked home. After dinner I attended at Saint John’s Church, where Mr Pine read Evening prayers for Trinity Sunday and another clergyman, a Stranger preached from Psalm 27.8. [“]When thou saidst, Seek ye my face; my heart said unto thee, Thy face, Lord, will I seek.”— Mr Hawley was not there; though he had been in the morning, and administered the Communion. He is in feeble health; and it is said Mr Pine is already engaged to be settled, as his colleague— President Tyler was there this afternoon. The heat of the day was so intense that I could write little.
3. V. Monday.

As I was stepping into my carriage this morning to go to the Capitol, I met Mr Giddings with Mr Bigelow, agent for the heirs of Francis Casaux, who were coming to see me. This Casaux claim, now of 67 years standing was before the house last Saturday in the shape of a Bill for the relief of the heirs of Francis Casaux reported by the Committee of the whole and put upon its passage for engrossment. The bill was opposed and I made some remarks expressing my doubts if there was any good foundation for the claim— The Bill was laid on the table— Mr Bigelow came to convince me of the justice of the claim— Mr Giddings having to call at a Department, went on; Mr Bigelow took a seat with me and went with me to the Capitol, reminding me on the way of his application to me as long since as 1832, for my testimony in this case which then or afterwards I gave in writing— Mr Bigelow brought me a report from the late Virgil Maxcy when solicitor of the Treasury; in favour of the claim— A motion was made by Dean of Ohio to reconsider the vote laying the bill on the table, and then the discussion was postponed to Friday, next. Charles J. Ingersoll moved a Resolution for a special assignment of next Monday and Tuesday, for the consideration and determination of such questions as are pending under treaties between the United States and Portugal, the Netherlands and Spain, and the resolution concerning the reciprocity treaties, with Denmark, Sweden, the Hanse-Towns and Great Britain. He dragooned the house into hearing his resolution read— Objections swarmed— He moved a suspension of the rules to enable him to present the Resolution, and called the yeas and nays— Lost 78 and 84— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, John W. Davis in the Chair on the Civil and Diplomatic appropriation Bill. When it came to the item of Stationary, Pollock moved a proviso that the Stationary should be purchased of American manufactured, and this sprung a debate upon the Presidential election, the Democratic National Convention, Clay, Van Buren, Polk, Tariff, Taxes, Oregon, Mexico, Lord Aberdeen and Democracy. Edward Joy Morris began the chace by denouncing the nomination of James K Polk as the Democratic Candidate for the Presidency. W. W. Payne, John J. Hardin, John P. Hale, Douglas, Schenk and Belser, bandied to and fro the party foot balls, with an episode of insult and defiance between Charles J. Ingersoll and Hale till near 5. O’Clock when the Committee rose and the House adjourned till 10. O’Clock to morrow morning.— I and others had mistaken the adjournment of this morning to be for 10— It was to 11.
4. V. Tuesday

I had promised yesterday to give Mr John Cranch one hour more for him to retouch his portrait of me with which he is not satisfied— But the morning was dark lowering and rainy, and it was half past 9. before I reached the lodge, and Mr Cranch preferred waiting till to-morrow for another sitting to taking of one of half an hour this day.— At the house Charles J. Ingersoll, offered a Resolution calling on the President for all the correspondence with the British Government relating to the exaction by them of duties on rough rice contrary to the Treaty of 1815— There was a snake under this foliage, for Ingersoll said it was harmless.— But Cave Johnson moved an amendment calling for all the documents relating to the Texian Treaty. Ingersoll objected to this amendment and advised and persuaded Johnson to withdraw it till at last he promised that all these Documents shall be communicated to the house, whereupon Cave withdrew his amendment and Ingersoll’s resolution was adopted. M’Kay then moved the Resolution to cease debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on the civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill, and take it out of Committee at 12 O’Clock to-morrow.— There was great pleading by White, Barnard and others to extend the time to Friday or Thursday, or to 4 O’Clock or 2 O’Clock P.M. to all such motions M’Kay stood inflexible, and called the previous question which was sustained and carried— There will of course be not one word of debate on this bill, bearing on the appropriations or having any reference to the bill itself—not one word relevant to the subject before the house. And so it would be if the debate were protracted to the last hour of the Session.— The house then went immediately into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, John W. Davis in the chair George Rathbun took the floor and poured forth an hour of glory and defence upon Martin Van Buren, and of vilification of Henry Clay.— Summers followed on the other side— Then alternately came Houston with M’Clernand, Peyton, Saunders, Bidlack and Foote of Vermont, till near 8. O’Clock in the Evening.— Foote’s speech was the most eloquent and the most decent of them all— Several motions for the Committee to rise were voted down, till twilight came, when on taking the question, upon a motion to rise, the majority voted against rising, but the whole vote was onlyno quorum— The Committee then rose per force and reported no Quorum— A motion to adjourn was rejected— A call of the house was refused by yeas and naysMotions to adjourn to 8 to 6. and to 4 O’Clock to morrow morning were made, till after lights had been brought into the hall—the house adjourned to the usual time.
5. V. Wednesday.

I gave an hour sitting to Mr John Cranch to retouch his portrait of me, and yet he did not finish— I promised him another At the house, immediately after the reading of the Journal I asked leave to present a report and bill from the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest. But M’Kay, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means moved to suspend the rules and go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and refused to allow me time to present my report and bill— The house went into Committee John W. Davis, in the Chair, and took up the civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill— Henley Of Indiana had the floor, and made one of the bitterest and most violent speeches against the whigs and Henry Clay that ever delivered in the house— He spoke of Pollock’s amendment requiring stationary of American Manufacture, as a species of whig humbuggery, which was an insult to the American People, and when called by name on the yeas and nays taken on this amendment he voted for it.— The temper of the Speech was in full keeping with its conclusion, which was the Standard of Henry Clay should consist of his armorial bearings, which ought to be, a pistol, a pack of cards and a brandy bottle— Tibbatts took the last house of the debate, allowing only ten minutes of it to Thomasson to back him in a motion to appropriate 550000 dollars to purchase a remnant of Stock in the Louisville, and Portland Canal to make it toll free— At 12 O’Clock the debate ceased and the voting commenced on the amendments, and continued till past 4. many of which were rejected, and a few were adopted— Pratt chairman of the Committee on the public buildings and grounds, moved a whole bill of amendments, usually presented in a separate bill; and I moved as an amendment to this amendment an item of 1000 dollars to erect in the Congressional burying ground a monument over the remains of the late Major General Alexander Macomb. The chairman decided Pratt’s amendment and mine to be in order and out of order three or four times, and finished by admitting Pratt’s items one by one, and excluding mine when the bill was reported to the house. Tibbatts renewed his motion for an appropriation to purchase the canal Stock—but the Speaker ruled it out of order.— The house then adjourned— Commander Wilkes, with the Revd Mr. Scoresby and a Mr Mayer spent the Evening with us. My wife received a Letter from our Son, of 2. June, safe home at Boston. [symbols]
6. V:30. Thursday.

Mrs Tayloe had written me a note requesting me to write two lines, with my signature, for Mr Von Raumer, who is to leave the City to-morrow. Instead of two lines, I wrote 24. but when written, I was unwilling to let them go from my own hands— They were utterly unfit to be read, and so it is nine times out of ten with lines which I am requested to write— I was unable to reach the lodge in time to give Mr Cranch a sitting for my portrait.— At the house Duncan had made a motion to the general appropriation bill, of an amendment to the item for refurnishing the President’s house, that no part of the appropriation should be applied to the purchase of wine— This was meant as a sly insinuation against H. Clay. But Hamlin had taken fire, and moved a Committee of enquiry to ascertain when and by whom, wine had ever been purchased under the name of furniture—but Pratt chairman of the Committee on the public buildings and grounds declared that he had examined all the accounts and that no such charge had ever been made.— Hammett made enquiry whether any answer had been received from the call heretofore made by Dixon H. Lewis for documents relating to the negotiations with Spain in 1816, 17. 18 and 19.— But the answer has not yet been received— The Reports, Majority and minority on the contested election between the Speaker and John M. Botts had been made the special order of this day.— Both the reports were in favour of Jones; but a Resolution had passed that Botts should be heard in support of his claim to the seat if he desired.— The first question was whether the competitors in arguing their claims should be limited by the hour rule, and after much debate it was decided by yeas and nays that they should be— The acting Speaker, Weller so decided— Garret Davis appealed from the decision— Cobb moved to lay the appeal on the table. Carried—102 to 76. I spoke against this construction of the rule.— Botts and Jones addressed the house for one hour, and they were both arrested without closing their argument— Elmer, chairman of the Committee then spoke in support of the Resolution declaring Jones duly elected and entitled to his Seat.— After which there was some jarring between Willougby Newton and Hannibal Hamlin, members of the Committee—and the vote by nominal call was answered 150 in the affirmative—none in the negative— The civil and diplomatic appropriation bill was then debated till 5. and the house adjourned. Evening call from Dr Brewer My wife, with Mrs Smith, Mrs John Adams and Mary Louisa went to a concert.
7. V. Friday.

Another last sitting to Mr Cranch for my portrait. At the house, M’Kay called for the consideration of the civil and diplomatic, and the navy appropriation bills, and Vance, chairman of the committee of claims, expressed a willingness to pass over the private bills for this day, upon condition that they shall be taken up to-morrow. But he pleaded for a short slip of time to call for the reports of Committees. Cave Johnson called on the Speaker, for a Letter from Charles A. Wickliffe Postmaster General, referring to a charge against him for official malversation, made on the 20th. of last Month, by Garret Davis, declaring the charge in every sense untrue, and that he is prepared to prove it so; and demanding an enquiry by order of the house. Garrett Davis said that he had stated the facts, and was prepared to prove them all true. As to the guilt of the Postmaster, he left that to be inferred from the facts which he had stated; and if Mr Wickliffe wanted enquiry as to the facts stated by him he was perfectly willing, and even to extend the enquiry to other charges against the Postmaster General, of similar character.— Cave the moved to refer the Letter to the Committee of Post-Offices and Post-Roads, with Liberty to send for persons and papers. Cave slyly observed that Garrett Davis’s charge this day was a little different from that which he had made before. Davis demanded in what particular it differed, and Cave had no reply to make.— His motion to refer the charges to the Committee of Post Offices and Post-roads was adopted, but Davis’s motion to extend the enquiry was lost.— M’Kay reported the bill-making appropriations for the unlawful naval expenditures— I moved to lay the bill on the table—lost—ayes 45.— It was referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union; where Barnard told me he wanted to debate it— Burke made a voluminous report from the Select Committee on the Rhode Island Rebellion, and moved that it be printed and postponed to the first Monday, in December next, which, after some debate it was carried, with agreement that a minority report, promised by Causin shall also be printed— I presented the report and Bill from the select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest, which were referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and ordered to be printed— The civil and diplomatic, and the Navy Appropriation Bills were taken up, and driven through, and just before 5. O’Clock the house adjourned MrColton, the author of Tecumseh—brought me a Letter of recommendation from Rufus Choate, and spent the Evening with me. Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary-Louisa went to an Evening party at Commander Wilkes’s.
8. V. Saturday

James Stevens a mulatto house servant who has lived with us during two Sessions of Congress has left us to go with Albert Smith who is employed to survey the North-Eastern boundary under one of the stipulations of the Ashburton Treaty— I gave a verbal and personal recommendation of James to Mr Smith— My morning hours after rising, are so constantly absorbed by newspaper reading and the evening hours by company or disability that I have no time except during the Session of the house to make up my record from day to day, which in the course of six hours I am usually just able to do. At the house Hopkins chairman of the Committee on Post-Offices and Post roads gave notice that he would next Monday move to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Post-Office bills, of which there are three— One from the Senate; one from the majority and one from the minority of the house Committee, each accompanied with a Bill and based upon antagonistical principles. All agree that some modification of the existing system is indispensable, or the general post Office will be ruined.— Newton moved that Mr Botts and the Speaker should have leave respectively to withdraw each for himself the testimony which he had produced before the Committee of Elections—but objections were made an amendment was first moved that they should have leave to take copies; and then it was remarked that they had a right to take copies without needing a resolution of the house and the motion was laid on the table.— Garrett Davis renewed the question he had yesterday made what Cave Johnson had meant by saying that his charge against the Postmaster General yesterday was different from that which he had made, and upon which Mr. Wickliffe by his Letter to the Speaker demanded investigation— Wickliffe’s Letter alledges that Davis had positively charged him with sending his agent into Davis’s district to interfere in the election against Davis and for his competitor, Wickliffe’s nephew— Davis had stated facts leading to that conclusion, and said he left the house to draw their own conclusion— Cave Johnson rather retreated from the discussion and Davis moved a suspension of the rules for a Resolution of enquiry by the Post-Office Committee generally of malversation by the Postmaster General. The suspension of the rules was refused 60 to 66— The house passed two bills relating to affairs of the district, and laid on the table several others passed the grant to the heirs of Casaux, carried the previous question for the Louisiana land bill, and then adjourned— After dinner at the President’s grounds. Met Garret Davis, John J Hardin and John H. Eaton— The Senate rejected the Texian Treaty 85 to 16 Hannegan absent.
9. IV:45. Sunday.

I attended this morning with my family, at St. Johns Church, where Mr Pine read the morning service for the first Sunday after Trinity, and Mr Scoresby preached from Isaiah 5.3. [“]And now, O, inhabitants of Jerusalem, and men of Judah, judge, I pray you, betwixt me and my vineyard 4. What could have been done more to my vineyard that I have not done in it? wherefore, when I looked that it should bring forth grapes, brought it forth wild grapes?” There is a singular transition from the third to the first person in the narrative of this wild but beautiful allegory. This seeming grammatical confusion is characteristic of the style of the Hebrew prophets and especially of Isaiah— This chapter is one of the most fearful predictions of the destruction of the two kingdoms of Israel and of Judah in the whole book of the Scriptures. With regard to the application of the text to the time and place, some question occurred to me of the propriety of the selection.— If this Country was to be considered as the vineyard of the Lord, for which he had done so much; all that could be done, and the vineyard had brought forth pernicious fruit instead of good fruit, was it for a stranger just landed on our shores then to use the language of reproach and the menace of destruction— But the preacher dealt to day only in generalities, expostulated only with individuals, and avoided all offensive imputations The boundless bounties of the Creator and the graceless ingratitude of the desperately wicked human heart was a theme upon which it was easy to expatiate at large— Mr Scoresby’s manner is earnest without extravagant, his composition grave and impressive, his pronunciation all English— Mr Hawley announced the death of Mrs Harrison Smith last Friday, and her funeral this day at one O’Clock. My family attended— I called at Fuller’s and returned the visit of Waddy Thompson, but he was out. Notice was given by Mr Hawley that this afternoon and henceforth for the Season, the evening service would commence at 5. O’Clock— But at 4. I attended at the second Presbyterian Church and heard Mr James Knox from Ecclesiastes 4.13 [“]Better is a poor and a wise child, than an old and foolish king”—leaving out the words, “who will no more be admonished”— It was a Sabbath School Sermon, abundantly democratic, and a collection was taken up for the Society— Mr Moseley of H.R, Mr Cutts and his daughter and a Mr Johnson of New-York passed the Evening here.
10. V. Monday—
The vote in the U.S. Senate on the question of advising and consenting to the Texian Treaty was
Yeas Atchison, Bagby, Breese, Buchanan, Colquitt, Fulton, Haywood, Henderson, Huger, Lewis, M Duffie, Semple, Sevier, Sturgeon, Walker, Woodbury 16.

Nays. Allen, Archer, Atherton, Barrow, Bates, Bayard, Benton, Berrien, Choate, Clayton, Crittenden, Dayton, Evans, Fairfield, Foster, Francis, Huntington, Jarnagin, Johnson, Mangum, Merrick, Miller, Morehead, Niles, Pearce, Phelps, Porter, Rives, Simmons, Tallmadge, Tappan, Upham, White, Woodbridge, Wright. 35.
Hannegan absent.

I record this vote as a deliverance, I trust by the special interposition of almighty God, of my Country, and of human Liberty, from a conspiracy comparable to that of Lucius Sergius Catilina— May it prove not a mere temporary deliverance, like that only preliminary to the fatally successful conspiracy of Julius Caesar— The annexation of Texas to this Union is the first step to the conquest of all Mexico, of the West India Islands, of a maritime colonizing slavery tainted monarchy, and of extinguished freedom.

At the house, Woodward was allowed to present resolutions of a meeting in South Carolina in favour of the annexation of Texas, and David L. Seymour presented Resolutions of a meeting in Rensselaer County New York against it—both were laid on the table— Pratt attempted to introduce a District banking bill, but failed— W. J. Brown proved to suspend the rules to make the Senate bill of appropriation for the continuation of the Cumberland road—lost by yeas and nays 82 to 83.— Ellis moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Post-Office Bill— All this time I was calling out at the top of my voice— Mr Speaker—to ask leave to present two petitions from native-Americans for alteration of the naturalisation laws—but the Speaker would not hear me— I called upon Ellis to withdraw his motion for me to present these petitions merely to have them referred to the judiciary Committee— Ellis haggled about withdrawing his motion till Bidlack took the floor from him and after dilly-dallying nearly a quarter an hour; whether he would or would not say what he had to say, closed by announcing the death of his colleague Almon H. Read on the 3d. of this month at his home in Pennsylvania, and he pronounced a strange eulogy on him, and offered the usual obituary resolutions and the house adjourned— I went into the Senate chamber and heard Thomas H. Benton introduce his bill for the annexation of Texas, and make a two hours speech in support of it— Conversation with J W. Huntington.— Evening visit from Mrs Madison and her niece Miss Paine—also from Mr Thom.
11. V. Tuesday.

The compositor of the Globe Office sent me the proof sheets of the Smithsonian bequest Bill reported by me from the Committee to the house in which there were several errors— I corrected them last evening; and took the corrected bill back to the office— I requested a proof copy of the report, also, when printed.— At the house, Weller attempted to introduce a resolution to give gratuities to the messengers, and pages as usual at the close of a Session, but failed— Cave Johnson moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, but withdrew it to allow me to ask leave to present two petitions for the alterations of the naturalization Laws.— I moved to suspend the rules; but on taking the yeas and nays the vote stood 35 to 94. Dromgoole asked if the petitions could be received under the rule by entering them at the Clerk’s table, and was answered that they would.— Two messages were received from the President one communicating the Treaty for the annexation of Texas, recently rejected by the Senate with all the documents relating to the Treaty published by the Senate, and others with a message of 16 May, not published by the Senate, and calling on Congress to accomplish the annexation. J. P. Kennedy moved to lay this message on the ta table, lost 59 to 118. by previous question it was referred to the Committee of Foreign Affairs.— Weller moved to suspend the rules for a motion to print 15000 copies of the message, lost 108 to 79. not two thirds. I moved to suspend the rules to offer two resolutions declaring the exclusive Constitutional power of Congress to declare War—and that any attempt by the President to negotiate the Country into a War by Treaty would be a violation of the exclusive constitutional authority of the house—lost 78 to 108— The other message was a veto of the Eastern harbour Bill, upon which by a rank cheat, and the previous question the vote on the bill was forced, and failed for lack of two thirds 103 to 83— The Naval pension bill, the Naval depot at Memphis Tennessee and the District Bank bill consumed the remainder of the day— The Naval pension bill went from the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Hannibal Hamlin in the Chair to the house and passed— The Distributions of debate on the District Banks to read it through were loaded with ribald invective against the whigs answered by Causin till the adjournment— Afternoon visits by Mr Stevens and Mr Perry— Evening party at Mrs. Madison’s to which none of us went.
12. V. Wednesday

list.item: Figaniere J. C de e Morao

div.p: My nephew Isaac Hull Adams left us this morning, engaged for engineer service, on the survey of the North-eastern frontier, appointed by Albert Smith the Commissioner charged with this work— At the house as the journal was being read, there was a marked omission in the proceedings of yesterday. I intended to move an amendment to supply the omitted part, when I was called out from my seat to Mr Brewer, who delivered me a Letter of introduction from Robert Monroe Harrison Consul of the United States at Kingston Jamaica.— Brewer is owner of a vessel just arrived at Alexandria from Jamaica; and going to Calais Maine where he belongs— I was out about 10 minutes, and lost the opportunity of moving the amendment to the journal— The army appropriation bill returned from the Senate, with all the curtailments restored, was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means.— Aaron V. Brown a personal explanation, giving the lie inferential to a paragraph in the Globe, being part of a speech of Thomas H. Benton in the Senate yesterday. Hopkins moved a joint resolution to pay half the funeral expenses of the victims of the explosion of the Princeton’s Peacemaker, from the contingent fund of the house— The other half to be paid from the contingent fund of the Senate— It was a very questionable measure both of constitunal and expedient argument, but after sundry twistings it was carried by yeas and nays 103 to 63.— After much struggling Campbell carried his resolution to take the District Bank Bill out of Committee of the whole at half past 12. O’Clock, and the house went into Committee upon it— Hannibal Hamlin, chairman— It was overloaded with vexatious amendments but was finally reported to the house— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union again Dromgoole in the chair, and Hopkins’s penal Post-Office bill was taken up and obstinately debated— Dana made a hard push to substitute the Senate bill for reducing the rates of Postage but failed— Hungerford moved a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday upon the vetoed Eastern harbour bill— The Speaker decided that the motion was not in order, from which decision I took an appeal. A motion to lay my appeal on the table, but was lost— A motion for the previous question upon it was also lost. It was six O’Clock and the house. The Portuguese chargé d’Affaires Figaniere called on me this Even- extremely urgent to have the Bill reported by the Committee of foreign Affairs in favour of an official claim by him, taken up and passed by the house.
13. V. Thursday.

I had little time this morning to prepare for the discussion of the question upon my appeal last evening from the decision of the Speaker, upon the motion to reconsider the vote on the vetoed Treaty.— There was a debate of three hours upon the question in the house; but the decision of the Speaker was sustained by yeas and nays 97 to 85 Jameson of Missouri, by suspended rules offered and carried a Resolution to take a recess from half past two to four O’Clock P.M this day and the succeeding days—till the close of the Session. Mr John P. Kennedy and Mr Winthrop invited me to dine with them which I did— I gave a Letter of introduction, to Edward Everett, our Minister at London, for George Rogers Clark, a son of the late Governor William Clark of Missouri, going to England, for his wife’s health— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Dromgoole in the chair— The supplementary naval appropriation was taken up D. D. Barnard moved an amendment, more explicitly declaring than M’Kay had done in his bill that almost the whole of these expenditures had been incured not only without authority of Law but in defiance of Law.— Barnard was followed by Ezra Dean, one of the rankest radicals in the house, who pronounced a philippic of an hour upon all parties, upon the last and the present Congress, interspersed with special venomous thrusts at the whigs—bewailing his disappointment in the expectation of reforms, and declaring that he would henceforth never take? the name of reform from in any other sense than as a humbug with unmitigated contempt— M’Kay commenced the defence of his bill, but was interrupted by the time for recess. I went and dined with Kennedy and Winthrop.— It was 5. O’Clock when we returned to the house— The naval appropriation bill supplementary had been resumed. Mr Barnard’s amendment was adopted; and the bill was passed.— The penal post-office bill was taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Hamlin Chairman; after a vote to take it out of Committee in 5. minutes.— D. D. Barnard asked leave to present, and moved to suspend the rules for 2 Resolutions of censure—upon Tyler’s usurpations— Suspension refused by yeas and nays 56 to 123.— The Light house bill—Army Appropriation Bill, Western Land sales bill, and Georgia dead horse bill, were successively taken up, and buffeted along in Committee and in the house till half past ten at night when the house adjourned, and I came home
14. V. Friday.

There was steady rain almost the whole day of yesterday and great part of last Night; and this day was of a temperature more congenial to October than to June. Dr. Laurie called on me this morning and renewed his solicitation for my interference, to obtain from the President of Mexico Santa Anna the release of Dr. William M. Shepherd a prisoner taken at Mier and confined in the Castle of Perote— I repeated a promise I had made before on receiving Dr Laurie’s Letter of 23 April last, that if Peace with Mexico should be restored, I would appeal to the humanity of General Santa Anna in behalf of Dr Shepherd and others of the Prisoners taken at Mier— Mr Waddy Thompson had already requested my good offices for them. At the house, this was the second of the last days of agonising confusion usual at the close of a Session of Congress.— It passes a spunge upon my memory, so that it is impossible to record the course of business, and can notice only a few of the incidents of the day.— There have been majority and minority reports from the Burke’s select Committee on the Rhode-Island memorial— Burke failed this day in a motion to print 5000 copies of his incendiary report.— Upon a Senate Bill to fix the Northern boundary of Missouri Augustus Dodge the delegate from the territory of Iowa hitched in an amendment authorising the People of that territory to form a State Government, with a surface of more than 100000 square miles.— The plundering Louisiana land claim bill was earnestly opposed, by Samuel F. Vinton, until the hour of the recess when I came home and dined— A message was received from the President with a large budget of the correspondence of George W. Erving in Spain from 1815 to 1819. not heretofore made public— It was the answer, to the call of the house, moved by Dixon H. LewisApril before his transfer to the Senate— I cursorily read over the papers and found abundant evidence to falsify the pretension of George W. Erving that he could have negotiated a boundary, even to the Colorado; but his instructions were not included in D. H. Lewis’s call.— This afternoon I asked leave to present a Resolution calling on the President for them— Reding objected— I moved and carried a suspension of the rules, and the Resolution was adopted— The Louisiana land claim bill, after a stubborn struggle was passed by yeas and nays 86 to 84. a reconsideration was afterwards moved, but the bill had been sent to the Senate, and White objected that in such case there could be no reconsideration. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Hopkins in the chair The amendments of the Senate to the civil and diplomatic, army, Indian and pension bills, were discussed, and reported to the house, which adjourned after 11. at night.
15. VI. Saturday.

The Revd. Obadiah B. Brown came this morning with a deed of release to him of his mortgage given as security upon his note for 1000 dollars taken by me in March 1842 in part payment of the debt of the Columbian College to me— On the 13th of last Month he paid the note-principal and interest in full and took it up with the mortgage.— In addition to this, a deed of release from the mortgagee is customary here; and I executed and acknowledged this one before two magistrates E. F. Brown, and James Lawrenson who came with him— I found the house in a chaos of confusion with two stupid resolutions against a bank of the United States reported from the Committee of elections by Chesselden Ellis, one of the weakest and most worthless turncoats in the house— They had been sprung this morning without notice or consultation with the minority of the Committee of Elections, and by the screw of the previous question moved by Ellis, were crammed down with the yeas and nays 108 to 68— A meaner and more despicable fraud was never perpetrated— There was something of consolation in what followed— Charles J. Ingersoll rose and without making any motion insinuated that the journal of 31. May required amendment.— It was there stated that I had presented a petition from citizens of Pennsylvania for an alteration of the naturalization Laws, and that it had been laid on the table— Since then he had received many Letters enquiring into the facts, and upon applying to the Clerk had been told that the petition had been withdrawn by me— If the petition was not on the clerk’s table, the Journal ought no to show that it had been laid there— The Petition was in my draw.— I took it out, held it up and said that in my anxiety to have it referred to the Committee, after enquiring of the Clerk whether it could not be so referred from the table without new application to the house and being informed that it could not I had borrowed it yesterday for the express purpose of moving that it be taken up and referred to the judiciary committee, which now I did.— The Speaker said could only be entertained by universal consent. I asked it.— Charles faintly said he saw no reason that it should not be referred— Reding objected— I moved a suspension of the rules and carried it by an overwhelming shout. Opposition slunk into silence, and the petition was referred to the judiciary committee— The same petition which 16 days ago by yeas and nays 128 to 24 refused to refer it, and laid it on the table— Ingersoll has raised a hornet’s nest about his ears by his double vote first against and then for laying the petition on the table. He has published a Letter to his constituents of the 4th. Congressional District of Pennsylvania to account for his double vote— His chief reasons are that the other Pennsylvania members save two, voted as he did at last, and
that the petition was presented by me— He did not like the [“]auspices.”— While the house was in its Babel state this morning, I went for a long hour into the Senate chamber where I found George M’Duffie, closing a violent and rancorous speech against Thomas Hart Benton, and his bill for the annexation of Texas— The bill was already laid on the table; but M’Duffie had obtained leave to answer Benton’s speech on introducing his bill— M’Duffie’s speech was unsparing upon Benton; and his reply of about one hour was so merciless and personal, that nothing but bodily fear, could have withheld the hand of M’Duffie from a challenge— But he put up with it, quiet as a lamb— I returned to the house where the Louisiana land bill, return from the Senate at the request of the house, was reconsidered, and after a metamorphosis, striking out all but one section it was passed and sent to the Senate again— From half past 2 to 4. O’Clock P.M. I came home and dined, and returned to the house— During the whole day and till after midnight the appropriation bills, civil and diplomatic, army-navy and Indian were time after time before the house, in and out of Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon amendments pending between the two houses and reports of Committees of conferences on disagreeing votes— In almost every instance the house finished by receding, as they did without one exception from all their retrenchments Though M’Kay had sworn to me that he would lose the civil and diplomatic, and the army bill sooner than give up the retrenchments which his Committee had introduced into them and which the house had sanctioned but after a second conference, he gave them all up, and the house submitted.— Ashe of Tennessee carried through a bill for establishing a naval depot at Memphis in that State against the opposition of the Mississippi and Louisiana, who wanted it in their own States— The whigs helped Ashe through.— The Cumberland Road, the bill to extend the Charters of the District Banks, and multitudes of private bills were urged upon the house in most admired disorder, one against the other, and by perpetual motions to suspend the rules rejected by yeas and nays or by tellers.— About 10 at Night conflict commenced between the District bank bill, and private bills, all at the third reading and under the previous question— Motions for a call of the house and to adjourn were followed up in alternate succession and always with demand for yeas and nays— Shortly before midnight R B Rhett moved to adjourn, and said that whether the house should adjourn or not, he would retire as the sabbath should commence— A motion to adjourn at 4 minutes past 12 was rejected— I desired that the time might be minuted on the journal— Soon after 2. the Senate adjourned— 20 minutes past 3 a motion to adjourn was made, and on the call of my name I answered no and fell asleep till E. R. Potter roused me and told me the house was adjourned
16. VII. Sunday.

There was no public worship in the hall of the house of Representatives this day— At St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley, Mr Smith Pyne engaged as his colleague or assistant, and Dr Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright of New-York were all present in Priest’s robes, and divided the morning services between them— Mr Pyne read the ordinary prayers and collects— Dr Wainwright the Litany and Communion and Mr Hawley gave out the notices.— Dr Wainwright preached a very excellent Sermon, from Proverbs 23.26, first part of the verse. [“]My Son, give me thy heart.”— The discourse commenced with an exemplification of the various senses in which the heart is used in the scriptures to indicate the properties of the human character— He quoted sundry passages of Scriptures in which the heart is significant of the understanding of the judgment of the Memory, of the Imagination, of the affections, and he might have added of the vices— The wisest of men does not appear to have analyzed the compound man, so as to discriminate between the operations of the intellect and of the affections— In the chapter from which this text was taken, is successively used to signify the seat of thought of deception, of wisdom of envy and of joy.— Jesus declared the first commandment to be, thou shall love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy Soul, and with all thy mind—that is with the affections, the intellect and the will— Solomon includes all in the heart— In this text the heart, Dr Wainwright thinks means exclusively the affections, and he builds upon it a theory that the first avenue to all religious Faith is through the senses— This must be true—but neither Trinity nor transubstantiation can be traced to this— After the morning service I had a visit from Daniel D. Barnard to take leave; and a long conversation with him— This Texas annexation we deem the turning point of a resolution which transforms the North-American Confederation into a conquering and warlike Nation. Aggrandizement will be its passion and its policy— A military Government, a large army, a costly Navy, distant Colonies, and associate islands in every sea will follow of course in rapid succession—a President for four years will be a laughing stock. A Captain General for life and a Marshal’s truncheon for a Scepter will establish the law of arms for the constitution, and the skeleton forms of War and Slavery will stalk unbridled over the land.— Blessed God deliver us from this fate!— After dinner Mr Pyne and Mr Hawley jointly performed the service, 2d. Sunday after Trinity— Mr Pyne preached from 2. Corinthians 7.10 For godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.
17. V. Monday—
Close of 28. Congress. 1. Session.

The first shock of Slave Democracy is over. Moloch and Mammon have sunk into momentary slumber— The Texas Treason is blasted for the hour, and the first Session of the most perverse and worthless Congress that ever disgraced this confederacy has closed. This last day from 10 in the morning till Noon was a continuation of tumult from the adjournment of yesterday morning. The joint Resolution of the two houses, had fixed the adjournment, by their respective presiding Officers at 12 O’Clock Meridian this day. There were numerous bills public and private still pending before them both, and the 17th. joint rule forbids the sending of any bill to the President for his approbation on the last day of the Session— This rule was rescinded and bills were sent to him and signed by him at least until the moment of adjournment. A printed notice signed by three lawyers, counsel for the 3 city banks, was laid on the tables of the members, stating that if Congress should not act on the bill for extending the charters, on their expiration, 4 July next they would be without power to recover any debts due to them— Campbell, chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia succeeded after a hard struggle in introducing a bill, which he called a compromise, giving the banks power after the expiration of their charters to prosecute and recover debts due to them, and making them accountable for their own, which bill was carried through and signed by the President— The inflexibility of the house against rechartering the banks, is said to have been wrought by the two brothers Carroll, one a whig member from the 29th district of New-York, and the other Clerk of the U.S. Supreme Court, and who is said to have a debt of his own of 20000 dollars to one of the City banks.— The Senate passed a Resolution to postpone the adjournment till two O’Clock, and while it was under discussion, in the House, the yeas and nays were called; in the midst of which call, the minute hand of the clock, pointing precisely at 12. the Speaker stop’d the call—declared the house adjourned without day, and left the chair. No Messages between the houses— No farewell to the President, and the members dispersed to their respective places of abode— Gilbert Livingston Thompson the Messenger sent to Mexico to snuff the scent of the Texian annexation Treaty there, returned this day, and reports that Santa Anna is ready and willing to treat for the cession of Texas to the United States. In the course of the day, I had visits from Mr George H. Colson, from the Revd. Dr Miller, and from Mr Connell, to take leave.
18. IV:30 Tuesday.

In the midst of the hurly burly of a closing session of Congress, a scene always sufficient to discompose the serenity of a steadier mind than mine, I have been distracted with multiplied applications for autographs and lines in Albums, which it would be ungracious and would be thought churlish to refuse, and yet with which it is insupportable to comply.— For many years I have occasionally written knacks, trifles, nosegays in the scrapbooks of my younger relatives, for which I have but a wretched talent, and inginuety could seldom save me from compliance— I once attempted to make a collection of these nugae albae; but I sickened at the sight of most of them and I gave it up.— A quarto volume, price ten dollars was published a few weeks since called the United States Album, with copperplate engravings of the arms of all the States in the Union, and fac-simile signatures of the President, of all the members of both houses of Congress, and of all the judges of the Supreme Court, and then blank leaves to be written upon.— A. H. Stephens of Georgia, Joshua R. Giddings of Ohio and Hamilton Fish, have each a copy of this book, and asked me to write my name and a few lines in them, and there I was straining from hard bound brains senseless rhymes, like the slipshod Sybil in lofty madness meditating song.— I went this morning to the Capitol, returned the volume of Dupuis which I had borrowed for Dr Todsen from the congress Library, and took out the 5th. volume of Thompson’s Alcedo.— Dr Muller Pastor of a Congregation of English Lutherans had invited me to attend at the ceremony of laying the corner stone of a Church last Thursday.— I was that day engaged at the house, but the weather was bad, and the ceremony was postponed to this day. Dr. Muller came yesterday and repeated the invitation to me to attend. Accordingly at 3 O’Clock this afternoon I went to the City Hall, and thence walked in procession of clergymen, church council of St. Paul’s congregation, teachers and pupils of the Sunday school; the Officers of the Grand Lodge of the Grand Lodge District of Columbia in full Regalia; the Sons of Temperance Society, and multitudes of boys, escorted by the Marine band, to the corner of H and 11th. Street, where the corner stone was laid of the English Lutheran Church of St. Paul’s.— There was a disgusting alliance of religious ceremonies with Masonic Mummery, but not a word could be heard of the address of the Grand Master who laid the corner Stone— The heat was excessive. Evening visit from Mr Joshua Dodge.
19. IV:30 Wednesday—

It sometimes happens at sea, that in the midst of a hurricane, the wind falls instantly into a flat calm, the sea still running mountain high— Ships in that condition are in extreme danger of rolling their masts overboard, and experienced mariners have told me, they dreaded such a condition more than the heaviest gale of wind— Such is my present. My attention to public affairs is absorbed in the preparations for settling my debts here, and in looking up the documents for the 2d. and third Sessions of the 27th. Congress, one set of each of which I am to pack up in a chest and send round by water to Boston— The Documents are now divided into three sets of 1. Executive Documents of the House. 2. Reports of Committees of the House 3. Senate Documents, including Executive and Reports— Then one Volume of Journals of Each house—and a Folio Volume or two of printed Bills and Amendments— I doubt if another member of Congress besides myself preserves an entire set of all these papers. Of the Bills no one condescends to keep a set After the close of each Session, every member of each house is entitled to receive bound one set of what are called the Session Documents, and one copy of the Journal of each house. But not of the Bills— During the Session each member has a copy of every printed document, and of every sheet of the Journals of both houses laid on his table fresh printed—these, like sybil leaves are scattered and destroyed from day to day— My practice is to have them kept in files for me, including the printed bills, and after the close of the Session to have them bound at my own expence— I have thus one set of the Documents here, and one at my home in Quincy. But many of the voluminous Documents are not printed till long after the close of the Session to which they belong. I found my sets of documents of both the second and third Sessions of the 27th. Congress incomplete and called at the Intelligencer and Globe Offices, and at the Clerk’s Office H.R.U.S. to rectify mistakes. French the Subclerk was gone to dinner, and I did not wholly discover where the error was, but am on its track.— I found by conversation with Gales, that Gilbert L. Thompson’s reports from Mexico were shameless lies, and that instead of Santa-Annas readiness to negotiate for the cession of Texas he took immediate measures for the most determined resistance. Treachery of the deepest infamy marks every step of this Jackson project for the dismemberment of Mexico and the perpetuation of Slavery from its inception to this day. It is yet portentous beyond conception— Mr Garrett Davis paid me a visit to take leave— He told me he was going home to Kentucky, and should return here in about 3 weeks, devoting the summer to an electioneering campaign.— Mrs W. S. Smith left us last Evening, and returned to Mr Frye’s.
20. IV:30. Thursday.

Mrs. Morris is the daughter of Mr John C. Spencer whose relations with the vicarious administration of John Tyler as President of the United States have been very remarkable— When in the summer of 1841. the rupture occurred between Mr Tyler and the whig cabinet of President Harrison— John C. Spencer, was President or Chairman of a whig association in the State of New-York and called an indignation meeting of whigs against Tyler at Syracuse— Before that meeting was held on the 12th. of October 1841. Mr Spencer was appointed by Mr Tyler Secretary of War, which Office he accepted and held, till March 7. 1843 when he was appointed Secretary of the Treasury— During the recent Session of Congress he was nominated a judge of the Supreme Court and on the 31st. of January last was rejected by the Senate. Since then, he resigned his office as Secretary of the Treasury, for which no reason has been made public; and on the last day of the Session of the Senate, was again nominated as judge of the Supreme Court, and again rejected— Mrs Morris’s husband was a clerk in the Treasury department while her father was the Secretary, and retires with him— I have little acquaintance with this Lady, but she has been very courteous to my wife and family, and earnestly solicitous that I would write some verses addressed to her— I did write a couple of Stanzas which puzzled me in the composition not a little— For I began with a line of seven syllables and in following out the verse fell unconsciously into the blunder of mingling 7 and 8 syllable lines together— I discovered it only by the want of harmony in the lines upon reading them over— I never before the peculiar property of the seven syllable line, which consists in the uniform location of the accent and emphasis on the first syllable of each line— The inadvertent admission of a word accented on the second syllable, changes the measure to the eight syllable verse, and the mixture of the two measures produces dissonance— It took me hours to Procrustesize my lines to Mrs Morris— She was here this day with Miss Paine, when I was out.— Miss Paine left word that I must not write any more verses for ladies— I proceeded in the assortment of my documents for the second and third Sessions of the 27th. Congress, visiting for that purpose, the Globe and Intelligencer Offices and the Clerk’s Office of the house. The bookbinder of the Globe had bound the five volumes of my Reports of Committees 27 Congress 2. Session in 6. whereby the contents of each volume did not correspond with the index.— French gave me in Exchange for the set, one duly bound.— He gave me also a set of the Senate Documents of the same Session which had not been delivered to me— Much of the day was consumed in settling accounts and paying off bills— Towards evening I rode with my wife daughter and granddaughter to the Eastern front yard of the Capitol, and heard the music of the marine band— Met there W. S. Archer, Senator from Virginia. Also William and John Cranch— The heat of the weather breeds idleness.
21. IV:30— Friday—

The settlement of my accounts; the payment of accumulated bills, the endorsement and filing of Letters, and the assortment of documents of the 2d. and 3d. Sessions of the 27th. Congress, still absorb my time, and delay the recovery of my arrears of Diary run up during the last days of the Session of Congress— The National Intelligencer of this day has my Letter of 18. May last to Mrs Sarah H. Butler President of the Ladies of the Wyoming Monumental Association at Wilkesbarre Pennsylvania—and I found it also, both in the Boston Courier and Daily Advertiser which came this day. I called again at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and obtained a copy of the paper of 7. June containing the fifth List of petitions presented by me to the House of Representatives at the first Session of the 28th. Congress, with the disposal of them by the house— The preceding lists are in the papers of 28. December 1843. 10 and 29. February and 5. April 1844— This last of 7. June contains also the Memorial of Edward Jarvis, William Brigham, and J. Wingate Thornton, the Committee of the American statistical association, demonstrating a multitude of gross and important errors in the printed Census of 1840.— On the 19th. of February last I had stated to the then Secretary of State Upshur that there were numerous errors in the printed census, and proved to him by inspection of the census itself the error of the return of 133 insane coloured persons in the town of Worcester, Massachusetts— On the 26th. of that month, the house at my motion, adopted a call upon the Secretary of State for a report whether any such material errors existed, and if so what had been done to correct them— The journal of the house of 4. May (p 887) states that the Speaker laid before the house a Letter from the Secretary of State (John C. Calhoun) in answer to the Resolution of 26. February, “stating that no such errors had been discovered”— On the 6th of May I moved to amend the journal of the 5th by striking out the words “and stating that no such errors had been discovered”— My motion was lost, by yeas and nays 32 to 126— On the preceding 18th. of April the same Secretary of State John C. Calhoun, in an official Letter to the British Minister Pakenham had drawn out an elaborate argument from these same falsified returns of the census as if they were uncontroverted truths, to justify the annexation Treaty with Texas.— On the 16th of May I moved a suspension of the rules to enable me to present this memorial, to the house and the yeas and nays on my motion were 93 to 47. The Speaker’s vote would have carried the two thirds required to suspend the rules; he declared it lost for lack of two thirds. I asked if he had voted he said he had not, and if he had it would have been in the negative— The next day I entered the memorial under the rule and it was referred to the Committee on Statistics whose Chairman Zadok Pratt promised me that they would report upon it; but they did not. At the house this day I obtained a copy of the House Journal 27. Congress 2 Session.
22. IV:30. Saturday.

Mrs Royall’s Sally called on me this morning to pay her annual visit, for collection of 2.50 for her weekly Newspaper called the Huntress. Mr William Emmons came and took back the volume of Boston Orations which he had lent me some months since, and of which he proposes to publish a new edition. Mr Lewis Johnson came and read to me a Letter from his Counsel Moffitt advising him to remit to the Administrator of Nathaniel Otis at New-Orleans the portion of William Otis’s Assets which would have been due to him if now living, leaving to the administrator to distribute the amount due to each of his heirs according to Lex Loci, in Louisiana— This I think right. Mr Johnson requested me to call again upon the first Comptroller and urge his decision upon the question of remaining interest on the claim of William Otis, which I promised to— I went accordingly to the Treasury Department, but the first comptroller was not at his office— I applied to Michael Nourse, Chief Clerk of the Register’s Office as Co Executor of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Will, for payment of two unclaimed dividends standing in his name—one of 67 dollars and 88 cents, from the Loan-Office book of Rhode-Island upon interest due in 1802–3 and 4. and the other, of 21 dollars 66 cents from the books of Massachusetts, and due in 1795— William Dayton Lewis 71. Cedar Street New York, had given notice of these two claims, by Letters of 9 and 23. May last to Nathaniel Curtis my Co-Executor, which Mr. Curtis had enclosed to me. I enquired if I could receive these dividends by virtue of the power of Attorney produced by me lastand upon which I received the dividend standing in the name of Lee, George Erving and Latham. Mr Nourse found that power, which did not include these dividends, but he paid them on my signing receipts there, for as Co-Executor, and promising to produce at my convenience authentic evidence of my right in that capacity.— He gave me an order on the cashier of the Bank of the Metropolis for 89 dollars 54 cents.— I had already called at that Bank, and exchanged for its bills 227. dollars 95 cents for 47 English Sovereigns which I had received there last Monday.— I went to the Globe Office—settled my bill there, and ascertained that the binder has my documents of the 27th. Congress 3. Session, from the document room to be bound— After dinner just before the setting of the Sun, I walked to the Presidents grounds, and heard the music of the Marine band— I met there Mr Smith Pyne, now assistant preacher with Mr Hawley at St. John’s Church. After which I paid a visit to Mrs Madison; who was going out; and lastly to Mrs Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, who has a soirée every Saturday evening. Mrs Tayloe once Julia Dickinson of Troy New-York, is literary and the pink of fashion— She shewed me three separate Albums, one of which contains autograph Letters from many of our revolutionary worthies.
23. IV:30. Sunday.

I attended public worship this morning alone at the second Presbyterian church, where Mr Knox preached from Luke 10.42— “But one thing is needful.” He premised this discourse with a narrative of the circumstances under which these words were spoken— The peculiar relation of tender affection between Jesus and this whole family of Martha, Mary and Lazarus— Then the incident which gave occasion to the remark, the extraordinary solicitude of Martha for the entertainment of her guests— Her call upon Jesus to bid her sister give some attention and assistance to the duties of hospitality, and the mild and gentle rebuke of Jesus to Martha for her excessive anxiety for mere worldly concerns with his approbation of Mary for adhering to the one thing needful, Religion. he proceeded with an earnest and affectionate exhortation to his hearers to apply to themselves that solemn injunction to every Christian, to devote himself and all his faculties to the one thing needful— Mr Knox read the whole of the 10th. chapter of Luke, which besides this account of the visit of Jesus to the house of Martha, contains also the question of the lawyer what he should do to inherit eternal life; and the answer of Jesus referring him to the Law—and asking how he reads the law? The lawyer replies Thou shalt love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind— The words, and with all thy strength, are here additional to the same saying as reported in Matthew 22.30. whether the illustration of the meaning of the term neighbour by the parable of the good Samaritan is not included— As I came out of the church I was accosted by Mr Fillebrown who told me that his father always a firm and good friend of mine died last week at the age of 81. He lived at Winthrop in the State of Maine.— This afternoon I attended with my family at St. John’s church where Mr Pyne read the evening service for the third Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Matthew 7.20— [“]By their fruits ye shall know them.” He began by observing that the judgment of the world was apt to require too much of Christianity by making it responsible for the faults and errors of its votaries— After some preliminary remarks he divided the discussion of his subject into three parts 1. What the world may justly expect from professing Christians 2. What it does require of them and 3. The practice incumbent on them in the fulfilment of their duties. He confined himself now to the first and second points, leaving the third for hereafter I walked this evening to Mr Gurley’s but Mr Davis was out.
24. IV:30 Monday.

I received last Friday a Letter from George R. Davis of Troy, New-York, asking my opinion if there was any thing in the course of David L. Seymour on the question of reconsideration upon the reconsideration of the Eastern harbour Bill, after the veto—that evinced any want of good faith or calculated to defeat a constitution at two thirds vote to pass the bill— Mr Seymour has been charged with this in a Troy newspaper, and Mr Davis, his neighbour and friends wants testimony to refute the Slander. Mr Davis was lodging at Mr Gurley’s on Pennsylvania avenue, and wrote me that he proposed to leave the City for home this day. I called last Evening at Mr Gurley’s to see him but he was out. He came here this morning, and I told him that before answering his Letter, I wished to see the Article in the Troy Newspaper containing the charge against Mr Seymour, but he had it not, and could state only the general purport of it. I told him that I could readily and cheerfully certify that I never for an instant entertained a suspicion of insincerity on the part of Mr Seymour, when the Speaker by what I thought a shameful collusion, cut off all reconsideration of the Eastern harbour bill, by deciding that the main question upon the previous question moved by Mr Seymour, applied to the passages of the bill, when not five minutes before Seymour had moved the previous question only upon an assurance from Linn Boyd, then in the Speaker’s chair that the main question would be on Seymour’s motion to postpone the reconsideration of the Bill from Tuesday to Thursday— This was a knave’s trick. I remonstrated against it in vain. If Mr Seymour had resented it vehemently I believe he would have shamed the Speaker out of it and the bill might have passed by a two thirds vote— Mr David L. Seymour was embarrassed by his reluctance to break with his Southern democratic allies; and submitted to the iniquitous decision of the Speaker which smothered all reconsideration of the bill. Mr Davis in substance admitted all this, and will be satisfied with my testimony to my belief in the sincerity of Mr Seymour— I was hard worked all this day in retrieving my arrears of diary run up in the last days of the Session— Towards Evening I walked to Mr Frye’s expecting to find my family there, but was disappointed— I found there however Mr and Mrs Moody with their infant daughter recently recovered from the scarlet fever— Walter Hellen was also there. I asked Mr Frye for a statement of his accounts as my agent here, and came home with Mr and Mrs Moody in their carriage—
25. V. Tuesday.

I called this morning at the Department of State and had a long conversation with the Secretary John C. Calhoun. I repeated the enquiry concerning the Documents required by the Government of Massachusetts from that of the Province of New Brunswick. He said the pressure of other business in the Department had delayed the renewed demand upon the British Minister for these papers, which he said he proposed to make next week— I then enquired about a memorial of James Crosby, and 90 others addressed to him and a printed copy of which has been sent to me.— It complains of enactments of duties by the Legislature of the Province in contravention to an article of the Ashburton Treaty— He said there was no doubt that it was a plain violation of the Treaty— And on this also he should address Mr Pakenham— My last enquiry was whether the call of the House of Representatives adopted at my motion on Friday the 14th. of this months, for the Instructions to George W. Erving in 1814 and afterwards during his mission to Spain had been answered— Mr Markoe told me that the Resolution of the house had not been received—another of the Clerks said it was not received until two hours after the final adjournment of the house, so that it cannot be answered till the next Session of Congress.— But Mr Calhoun immediately offered to send to my house for my inspection the two folio of manuscript Volumes of Instructions to the Ministers of the United States in Europe—which I accepted— And in the Letter of Instruction from James Monroe Secretary of State of 30. May 1816. I find the following passage “On the cession, by the Spanish government of all claims to territory Eastward of the Mississippi, he (President Madison) is willing should it be indispensably necessary to establish the Sabine from its mouth to its source as the boundary in that extent, between the United States and the Spanish Provinces; leaving the residue of their boundaries to be settled by Commissioners to be hereafter appointed by both governments.” other parts of that instruction are not less important, and have never before been published— Dr Müller the pastor of the English Lutheran Church came this afternoon with the subscription book for the church— Y. B. Page, brought me from the Secretary of the Senate and Clerk of the house one copy of the American Archives fourth Series fourth vol— Mr Lawrenz whose cotton manufactory I visited at Pittsburgh was here with his wife, accompanied by Mr and Mrs Hubbard of Massillon, Ohio. My wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter with Mary Cutts, took tea and spent the Evening at Mrs Frye’s— I walked there and came home with them.
26. IV.30. Wednesday.

On Sunday the 6th of September 1840 I passed the day at Cornwallis in Nova Scotia. In the morning I sallied forth in search of a church, and as I walked, a man in a chaise with one horse passing by me stop’d and offered me a seat with him which I accepted and went with him to church— His name was Harris— He was a respectable magistrate of the place, and he called on me this morning, being on a summer excursion into the States. He told me candidly that he did not think what he had seen of this Country, equal to Nova Scotia— The town of Cornwallis, is one of the most fertile spots in the province; a great portion of it having been reclaimed from the Sea— I continued my preparations for departure, and returned to the Congress Libraries, books which I had taken out to use. Among those that I may want again are Howell’s State trials vol. 20. for the case of the Negro Somerset— It is also in Capel Loft’s reports but not so fully reported— Barnewall and Cresswell’s Reports, 2, p 448 The case of Forbes and Cochrane— And Haggard’s admiralty Reports 2. 94— Case of the slave Grace—in which Lord Stowell did his worst to reverse the decision of Mansfield in the case of Somerset, as Mansfield reversed the decision of Lord Hardwick twenty years before him.— I returned also the Volume of Thompson’s Alcedo, and took out Black’s translation of Humboldt’s Political Essay on the Kingdom of New Spain. 4 Vols 1822. “Dernieres Decouvertes dans L’Amerique Septentrionale, de M. de la Sale, Mises au jour par M. le Chevalier Tonti, Gouverneur du Fort Saint Louis, aux Islinois. Paris 1697.— Journal Historique du dernier Voyage que feu M. de la Sale fit dans le Golfe de Mexique, pour trouver l’embouchure, et le cours de la Riviere de Missicipi, nommee a présent la Riviere de Saint Louis, qui traverse, la Louisiane— Ou l’on voit l’Histoire tragique de sa mort, et plusieurs choses curieuses du nouveau monde—par Monsieur Joutel, l’un des compagnons de ce Voyage, redigé et mis en ordre par Monsieur de Michel.[”]— Paris 1713.— And a Translation of this work, london 1714. I returned to Asbury Dickins the Journal of the Senate for the 3d. Session of the 27th. Congress which they had lent me, at the commencement of the recent Session, and Dickens gave me three copies of the proceedings of the Senate on the Treaty for the annexation of Texas.— The pamphlet Speech of W. C. Rives on the Tariff, and Major Graham’s map, of our Northeastern boundary as settled by the Ashburton Treaty— I ascertained that George W. Erving was not nominated as chargé d’Affaires to Constantinople. David Porter was nominated Consul General at Algiers 1829. Chargé d’Affaires to Constantinople 1831—Minister Resident in 1839. an increase of rank and pay for the sole purpose of petting him; and now they have given his widow an outfit as a posthumous gratuity— I paid a visit this Evening to Mr Pakenham whom I found with his family at dinner.
27. IV:30. Thursday.
Fahrenheit 90— Potowmac Bath.

This day set in the extreme heat of the summer—the trial of the climate to my Constitution. A burning Sun— The thermometers in my chamber at 90 and a light breeze from the Southwest, a fan delicious to the face, but parching instead of cooling the skin— I have been a full month for a river bath without daring to take it— This morning at 5. I went in the Barouche to my old favourite spot—found the tide unusually high— All my station rocks occupied by young men, except one, and that surrounded by the tide, already upon the ebb.— I had some difficulty to undress and dress, but got my bath—swam about 5 minutes, and came out, washed and refreshed— It was my exercise for the day— After returning home I did not again pass the sill of the street door— I continued the process of packing up books and papers to send to Quincy— I found the blue chests N. 11. and 14 with their keys, and another, blue chest without key or number.— The chest furnished me by the Postmaster of the house holds not half the books and documents accumulated in the second and third Session of the 27th. Congress— On opening the blue chest N. 11. and the one unnumbered which had not been opened for several years, I found a mass of old Letters and secret documents of which I must if life and health be indulged me till the next Session of Congress make a thorough and systematic revisal— On a cursory glance at Humboldts New Spain I find at Vol. 2. p. 229. Chapter 8. Section 10. Intendancy of San Luis Potosi, notice of the claim of the United States to Texas under the Louisiana Treaty; and the very distinct opinion of the author against it.— I find also two important facts to be hereafter noted— First, in Joutel’s Narrative of La Sale’s last voyage—of his death by a musket ball fired by a man of his own company named Duhaut, on the 19th. of March 1687. page 201— Secondly in Tonti’s book published in 1697.—p. 329 speaking of his own wanderings in the Country of the Nanadiches,—he says, “Nous quittames leur pays le 29 du Mois de Mai (1690) et nous avançames jusqu à une journée des Palaquessons. Ce sut là que nous apprimès que la derniere Colonie etablie par M. de la Sale sur les bords de la Mer Mexique, n’aiant pu se maintenir dans une parfaite Union, s’etoit toute dispersée; que les uns s’etoient confondus avec les Sauvages, et que les autres avoient pris le parti de remonter vers les habitations Francoises.”— [“]C’est pour quoi n’aiant pas cru devoir les aller chercher ou ils n’etoient plus, je me resolus de revenir sur mes pas”— In the same book p. 192 is the account of La Sale’s first discovery on the 7th. of April 1683 of the Mouth of the Mississippi river, descending from Canada, the Lakes and the Illinois— Mr and Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us, and Doctor Frye was here this evening.— I answered a very strange Letter lately received from Thomas F. Marshall, who seems disposed to make a witness of me against Henry Clay.—
28. IV:15. Friday
Fahrenheit continuously at 90.

The extreme heat of the weather reduces my condition to a state little above mere vegetation— I have had for a succession of years repeated invitations to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum at Frankford 6. miles North of Philadelphia; and have repeatedly promised at some time to comply with this request— I had concluded to go to Philadelphia next Wednesday—to devote the Evening to the Frankford Lyceum—return then to Philadelphia, and pass the 4th. in quiet there— But as the time appraches difficulties are started— I am so much debilitated and prostrated in physical strength by the heat, that I feel an invincible repugnance to undertake a speech in public before strangers— So I postpone our departure for home till Monday the 8th. of next Month, and halt only for the Night at Philadelphia— This morning I had a visit from my old friends, Richards and Ha-lilio. Ambassadors from the Sandwich Islands; now on their return from their Mission to England and France. They succeeded in obtaining from the Governments of both those Nations professed acknowledgments of them as a Sovereign Independent Nation—but in the mean time—Lord George Paulett, commander of the British took possession of the Islands in the name of Queen Victoria— This measure effected on the 25th. of February 1843. was disavowed by the Queen, and on the 31st. of July 1843. King Kamehameha the third, was restored to the sovereignty of the Islands by treaty with commodore Richard Thomas Commander of the British line of Battleship Dublin. But I learn by a private Letter from our Commissioner to the Islands dated at Honolulu, 19 and 23. Feby 1844. that on the 5th. of that Month the English Corvette Hazard arrived there from St. Blas and Mazatlan having on board the English Consul-General Mr Miller, who shortly after concluded with the king a Treaty, by one Article of which English subjects are to enjoy in the Islands all the privileges of natives—by another not more than 5 per cent duties are to be levied upon Articles imported from England, without reciprocity; and by a third, the British Consul is authorised to appoint the jury for the trial of any British subject, charged with any crime— Mr Richards was conscious that these Articles were scarcely compatible with the pretensions of a Government to absolute Sovereignty and Independence; and admitted our right to claim for citizens of the United States the benefit of all these Articles, as much as if they had been concluded with us— These Commissioners had not yet seen the Secretary of State, or the President, who returned this day from New York with a wife of 22. Julia Gardiner, daughter of David Gardiner of Long Island, who was killed by the bursting of the gun in the Princeton last February. They were married by bishop Onderdonk, in the Church of the Ascension, the day before yesterday, at New-York.
29. IV. Saturday.

The summer heat and its enervating spell continues— I walked this morning to my old bathing station upon the strand of the Potomac river and bathed and swam for about 10 minutes, and then walked home— From the practice of personal ablution and the exercise of swimming I cannot totally abstain, for I believe they have promoted my health and prolonged my life many years. And yet the experience of late years has compelled me gradually to disuse them— But my great anxiety now, is having much to do, and to be doing nothing.— I called at the Globe Office, and saw Mr Kane the book-binder of that establishment— He has my file of Documents for the 3d. Session of the 27th. Congress; they are not complete, and I requested him before binding them to send to Mr French the sub-Clerk of the house, to have the missing papers supplied. I returned to the Globe office a remnant of the numbers of the Congressional Globe of 1842—found among my loose papers since I returned the rest— I called at the Patriotic Bank, and left my book there to be balanced. Then at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and saw Mr Gales— I took a paper of the 27th. containing my Card to take leave of all invitations to public meetings.— It contains also a remarkable speech of W. S. Archer in the Senate against the advice and consent to ratify the Treaty for the annexation of Texas to the United States.
