At the Office of the Clerk of the House, French was not there— I requested of the Clerk who was there a copy of the memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr, and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for an alteration of the naturalization Laws, so as to require 21 years of residence by foreigners before admitting them to all the privileges of native Americans— This was the first memorial presented to the house on the subject— I moved its reference to the judiciary Committee but it was laid on the table by yeas and nays. 15 days after it was at my motion taken up from the table and referred to the Committee on the judiciary— The clerk promised me a copy for Monday next with the names of the signers. I shall see whether the Editors of the National Intelligencer will publish it— I declared in the house that I should not hold myself bound to support the demand in the house; but at the next Session on the native American party will be heard in both houses, and the proceedings of house on this first memorial, will have a material influence upon the debate. Mr Frye came this afternoon and gave me the accounts of his agency for my private affairs in this City— They have remained unsettled several years till I am afraid to look at them— I have shrunk from the task too long. I walked this afternoon to the President’s grounds, and heard there the music of the Marine band— Met there Mr and Mrs Morris son and daughter of John C. Spencer, beau Laurence, B. O. Tayloe, Mr Pyne and General Daniel Parker who pointed to old Cooper at Galabrun’s door.
30. V. Sunday.

Cooler— Fahrenheit down to 84. At the second Presbyterian Church, Mr Knox preached from Matthew 23.33. “How can ye escape the damnation of hell?”— He read the whole chapter of tremendous denunciation of Woe, eight times repeated against the Scribes and Pharisees, for their hypocrisy.— This discourse was held almost immediately before the arrest, trial, sentence and execution of the Messiah— It is in this chapter also that occurs the pathetic, and affecting prediction of the destruction of Jerusalem— There is no mention of pharisees in any book of the old Testament— Nor in the apocryphal books— But they are found in the New Testament as a profession, of half Priests, half Lawyers, invested with authority, for Jesus says they sit in Moses seat and with his bitterest reproaches upon them, he enjoins upon his disciples implicit obedience to their authority— The believed the resurrection, the existence of Angels and Demons, and the retributions of a future state— They veiled their vices therefore with hypocrisy, and made great show of rigid and austere virtue— He charges them with prevarication, cruelty, extortion and excess, all under the disguise of hypocrisy— And this was the class of man, of whom he demanded how can ye escape the damnation of hell? Is it a suitable enquiry to make of Christians in communion with the church? It is inconceivable to me, how men of decent character can suffer themselves to be treated from week to week like the vilest malefactors— It seems to me as if the preacher considered himself as a chaplain to a penitentiary, discoursing to the convicts.— After dinner at St. John’s church Mr Pyne read the evening service for the 4th. Sunday after Trinity and preached the remainder of his Sermon, begun last Sunday from Matthew 7.20. “By their fruits ye shall know them.”— The divisional part which he had left for consideration this day, was the third and last— The extent to which the world does hold the deportment of the Christian man, by which he appeared to understand the Christian minister responsible to them— He said they were often censured for not wearing an unalterably cheerful appearance and he assigned various reasons why the Christian man should were an appearance of gravity— Sometimes he said they were censured for the opposite property of hilarity unbecoming the Christian profession, which he considered equally unreasonable. The discourse was upon the whole a dissertation upon the injustice of the judgments of the world, and upon the duty of maintaining a spirit of independence against them; indicating a consciousness of the necessity of self-vindication. I answered this evening a Letter received last January, from a young man named Thomas W. T. Curtis, enclosing, a mutilated copy of my Vision—in the hand-writing of Mary Frazier.
